Marc Fennell:
G'day, my name is Marc Fennell and welcome

2.83.text:
to the MindMatters spotlight on Bullying.
Now, bullying in schools; it is just one of

7.27.text:
those issues that never, ever seems to go
away but we are going to take a crack at it

11.57.text:
today. With me are Adjunct Professor Ken Rigby
from the University of South Australia, we’ve

15.90.text:
got Sandra Craig from the National Centre
Against Bullying, Susan McLean from Cyber

20.17.text:
Safety Solutions and Lyn O’Grady from the
Australian Psychological Society. Before we

23.82.text:
start, I just want a show of hands; who here
was bullied in school? Right, okay. So, with

30.49.text:
that Susan, is it not just a part of everyday
life that everybody has had to put up with?

35.22.text:
If you had somebody in front of you that thought
that way, what would you say to them?

38.55.text:
Susan McLean:
That bullying is not an acceptable part of

41.11.text:
growing up. That no matter what anyone says,
words do hurt; they stay with you forever.

46.89.text:
And I think that it’s not part of adolescence,
it’s not part of school life, it doesn’t

51.57.text:
make you tougher or better or smarter or more
resilient because you’ve been bullied. It

56.82.text:
is a form of abuse and we need to take it
seriously.

59.05.text:
Marc Fennell:
So, do you think we need to change the way

60.96.text: we think about bullying, as an industry?

62.98.text:
Susan McLean:
I think we’ve got to be very careful with

64.90.text:
term because often when you talk to adults
about bullying, immediately they do, “It’s

69.56.text:
a kid thing. I was bullied when I was a kid
and look at me now; I’m big and tough.”

75.63.text:
And we also need to make sure that we don’t
lump everything into bullying because there

79.76.text:
are a lot of behaviours that are mean and
nasty and disrespectful but they’re not

83.83.text:
bullying. So, making sure that we use the
terminology correctly because otherwise we

89.91.text:
Marc Fennell:
So then Lyn, how do you break down the definition

94.98.text:
Lyn O’Grady:
We can talk about three different areas, really.

97.25.text:
So, we can talk about overt bullying which
is the physical, obvious bullying that we’re,

102.03.text:
perhaps, all very aware of and you can see.
Then there’s the covert bullying which is

106.30.text:
the much more hidden, so much harder to actually
identify and much more subtle, so the sneakier

111.68.text:
kind of bullying. And it can be exclusion,
it can be isolating, it can be rumours, whispering;

117.36.text:
just hard to pin down so it can be really
difficult to tackle. And then, of course,

121.39.text:
more recently with the advent of technology
we’ve got cyberbullying and that brings

125.24.text:
a whole lot of other areas of concern, as
well. And again, it can be online using technology,

132.49.text:
so the same sorts of behaviours and attitudes
but using technology to do that.

136.44.text:
Marc Fennell:
Is there one overarching strategy that you

139.71.text:
can take to tackle bullying? Imagine you’re
sitting in front of a room full of teachers

143.17.text:
right now and that’s who you’re talking
to. Is there one starting point that they

146.96.text:
Lyn O’Grady:
I think the building of relationships within

149.29.text:
schools has to be really a conscious effort
and I think it has to be built into policies,

155.19.text:
it has to be built into practices, it has
to be built into protocols that teachers agree

160.51.text:
to following. And you then have people modelling
for young people the sorts of behaviours that

167.83.text:
Ken Rigby:
I think one of the things that - again, is

169.42.text:
coming out of a recent study - is that the
use of circle time, meetings which students

176.90.text:
can actually sit around with a teacher and
talk about the things that really concern

181.48.text:
them, and very often bullying comes up. That
kind of exercise, meeting of that kind, are

188.58.text:
very welcome to students; students say there
should be more of them. And they tend to happen

192.69.text:
in primary school but not secondary; I think
it should happen more at secondary. And it

196.95.text:
improves relationships, it gets people to
see that they’re very often all in the same

201.18.text:
boat and they should be helping each other.
It’s not a situation we should try to solve

206.57.text:
the bullying problem, but you’re improving
relationships; relationships not only between

210.55.text:
the students but also with the staff, with
the teacher, and making it possible for people

216.90.text:
to come together and to use the kind of strategies
that you’ve mentioned. But it’s a very

220.99.text:
important preliminary step, I think, a preventive
step, that I think there should be more of it.

225.96.text:
Marc Fennell:
What about when something does go wrong? When

229.38.text:
Lyn O'Grady:
There’s a lot of different efforts, I suppose,

232.52.text:
that schools have been going to for a long
time around this and some of them don’t

237.13.text:
work very well at all but others do. So it’s,
I think for a school to work out what is it

242.53.text:
that we need to put in place, well before
the incident happens. And there are approaches,

247.23.text:
whether it’s restorative practices or method
of shared concern. So, there are particular

251.28.text:
approaches that require investment in training
and resourcing teachers so that you’ve got

256.01.text:
some understandings, you’ve got people who
are well trained and well equipped to do that.

259.68.text:
So, it’s not necessarily something you do
at the time, it’s something that, again,

263.02.text:
is part of that whole planning, part of policies,
part of work with families and with students

268.24.text:
Susan McLean:
And it’s not ‘one size fits all’.

270.93.text:
Susan McLean:
Because what works here, does not always work

273.81.text:
there. So, you’ve got to be aware of what’s
going to work best for you and you might have

277.77.text:
to change; this particular situation might
not actually work.

282.60.text:
Ken Rigby:
Look, I agree very much that it’s necessary

287.31.text:
to deal with different kinds of bullying in
different sorts of ways. There’s no one

293.44.text:
way of dealing with bullying because there
can be very serious bullying which people

298.47.text:
have been violently assaulted and in cases
like that it’s entirely reasonable to use

304.19.text:
some kind of sanction, indeed you must if
it’s of a criminal nature. The other extreme,

311.07.text:
there are certain non-punitive methods which
work extremely well.

315.47.text:
Ken Rigby:
Well, there’s shared concern. This is a

318.87.text:
method that begins when someone or a group
of people are suspected of having upset somebody;

326.92.text:
suspected. There’s no charge, there’s
no accusation. They’re invited one by one

334.99.text:
to talk about the plight of the child that
is having a bad time. And rather than accuse

343.51.text:
these individuals, you say, “Well, I’d
like to talk with you about what’s happening

347.23.text:
and how this person can be helped because
he’s really in a bad way.” And very often

351.82.text:
in a one-to-one situation with the right sort
of approach, you can get the suspected bully

358.73.text: to come forward with some sensible suggestion.

360.91.text:
Marc Fennell:
What about the bullying that we can’t see?

363.14.text:
Susan McLean:
So, I think if in the school environment if

365.94.text:
you’re dealing with an issue of cyberbullying,
and every school has it. There is not a school

370.00.text:
in the world that does not have this going
on currently, to date, right now. But it’s

376.19.text:
not so much reading the piece of paper that
where ‘Mary’s called Sally a fat cow’,

381.27.text:
it’s not so much that because that would
normally manifest itself at school by a changing

385.26.text:
social cohesion in the class. You know, previous
friends are not friends any more, you’ll

389.89.text:
see isolation happening. So through that,
then when you have your conversation you can

395.08.text:
then find it was because, “I was excluded
last night online” or “Someone sent a

399.30.text: nasty text message” or things like that.

401.47.text:
Marc Fennell:
Does technology itself play a role? Are there

405.43.text:
ways that the school can employ websites,
apps, something technical that can go some

411.27.text:
way to fixing cyberbullying or is it really
about culture and imbuing that sense of value

416.54.text:
Susan McLean:
I think that cyberbullying is not about the

419.17.text:
technology, it’s not a social media site’s
fault, it’s not an app or a device’s fault;

424.54.text:
it’s the person pressing the buttons. So,
it actually - it’s absolutely a thing where

429.55.text:
the person is in control. The technology is
the conduit; it’s allowing it to happen.

434.66.text:
Marc Fennell:
Susan, this is what you do; you work with

437.18.text:
schools and you work with families. What are
some great examples that you’ve seen where

440.29.text: schools have managed that dynamic really well?

443.09.text:
Susan McLean:
Ultimately, parents want the best for their

445.63.text:
children. It doesn’t always come across
that way. It’s a very sensitive and emotive

450.31.text:
issue, so it’s about remaining calm. And
as Sandra said, the processes; knowing them.

455.96.text:
“If you come and tell me this, this is what
you can expect of me. Remember, you read it

461.40.text:
at the start of the year when you read our
policy manual.” So, you’re not winging

464.90.text:
it, you’re not doing it on the fly. Like
anything, if you lay the foundations you are

470.37.text:
Marc Fennell:
Ken, I want to talk to you about families.

473.16.text:
What are really great examples of schools
using that relationship with families to get

478.43.text:
a positive result that you’d like to see
more of?

481.13.text:
Ken Rigby:
We’re finding that about a third of parents

485.03.text:
in a recent survey said they didn’t know
whether the school had a policy or not. Certainly,

490.12.text:
making sure that every parent knows what it
is, and that’s important. And the other

494.84.text:
thing too, of course, is being able to respond
to parents, parents know that the school is

500.81.text:
taking this seriously and they want input
from the parents. If your child is being bullied

505.31.text:
then, of course, the will parents feel very
strongly that he or she has a right to go

510.61.text:
to the school and to get things fixed. It’s
interesting, as far as cyberbullying is concerned,

515.88.text:
because I think there’s been quite a big
change recently. At one stage schools were

519.91.text:
saying, “It’s out there, it’s nothing
to do with us.”

521.89.text:
Lyn O’Grady:
I think it’s really challenging and it will

523.69.text:
depend on different schools and different
- there are cultural aspects to this, there

527.60.text:
are different ways that communities and schools
will operate within that. I think that the

531.89.text:
whole school approach to really helping staff
recognise that parents continue to play a

537.15.text:
really active role in the lives of young people,
so I think there’s still some confusion

540.93.text:
around that. But at the same time, we do need
to empower young people and we do need to

544.51.text:
help them to be able to make some of their
own decisions, make their decisions about

548.47.text: at what point do they need to seek help.

551.16.text:
Sandra Craig:
We need to ensure that they’re welcomed

556.75.text:
in the school and that they’re part of the
relationship culture, and that’s also part

If there was one last thought you could leave

thought that you could give them? Something
practical, something that they could do today.

571.34.text:
You will all get to answer this but we’ll
start with you, Lyn.

573.14.text:
Lyn O’Grady:
I think listening to students and being curious

576.50.text:
about what’s going on with them, so relationships.
But really listening and believing what they’re

581.16.text:
Marc Fennell:
You got in with the relationships first; you’re

583.64.text:
giving them nothing else to go on here. Sandra,
what’s your one?

586.71.text:
Ken Rigby:
Well, I’d extend it beyond that and say,

588.07.text:
I think we all agree connections with parents
because parents care. I mean, they do actually

594.58.text:
care enormously compared with, sometimes,
teachers. They’re concerned about their

599.19.text:
own child and then - well, a lot about their
child - and they do deserve, I think, to be

listened to perhaps much more than is the
case. So, better connections with parents,

I think is very important, as well as better

614.36.text:
Sandra Craig:
That was what I was going to say. No. It’s

618.91.text:
Sandra Craig:
It’s very, very important for teachers and

621.71.text:
parents both, to recognise the signs of the
bullying in their student or their child and

629.08.text:
Marc Fennell:
And Susan, the final word to you.

631.37.text:
Susan McLean:
Have policy in place, review it, make it well

635.03.text:

Marc Fennell:
